subject: OT (RE: [junit] Experience with jdk1.4 assert keyword)
msgSnippet: ... Why is something like assert foo != null : Foo null ; a bad thing? There looks to be nothing wrong with it, except that it I *should* be able to write my
messageBody:
On 1/16/2002 at 10:51 AM STRAYER, JON (AIT) wrote:
>
>and certainly NOT a way to enforce runtime checks.
>
> They are
certainly bad if you use them to catch bugs in
> production code "before
they happen" (example: testing
> for null in a place where you should
never get a null
> reference), in the same way that it's a bad idea to
use
> exceptions to control normal program flow.

Why is something like
assert foo != null : "Foo null";
a bad thing?
 
There looks to be nothing wrong with it, except that it I *should* be able to write my methods this way:
 
public void doSomething(final String withMe not null) {
...
}
 
Let the compiler generate the assert. It's the damn computer; not me. :)
 

J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
Let's write software that people understand.
http://www.diasparsoftware.com/
